content.description: Fairly steep edging leads past two bolts (11d) to a bit of a runout to the third and last bolt.  Above the last bolt 5.9 runout climbing leads to the top.  This is one of the better face routes in the area.
content.protection: 3 bolts.  Take some gear for the anchor.
content.location:
On the face just right of

Jammit

.

content.description:
This route was originally bolted by a party that couldn't do it.  Eventually, Levy and Mike (not the bolters) toproped it.  Not sure if it's ever been led.

Steep and powerful face climbing leads past three bolts.  Kind of a short route.

climbs.name: South Arete
climbs.fa: Tom Gilje and Scott Erler, January 1988

content.description:
A great route that follows an arete on steep rock.  Start by doing a short bit of crack to get to the arete.  Climb past 6 bolts.  The arete yields superb climbing in a great position, with the crux approximately halfway up.

Tom Gilje originally lead the route with only three bolts, all placed on lead.  The other three bolts were added at a later date.  While doing it, imagine what it would be like with only three bolts...
content.location: On the left edge of the Le Dent Pinnacle proper.

content.description: This route follows the left side of the Le Dent Pinnacle.  Pitch 1 (5.7) follows a novel, fun enclosed chimney.  You can rappel from there, or do the unprotected 5.6 second pitch to the top.
content.protection: a few pieces up to a #4 camalot

climbs.name: Reunion
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett and Dave Black, August 1991

content.description: This short, gymnastic face climb has fun moves and excellent protection.
content.protection: 3 bolts plus some wired nuts and small cams for low on the route, and a #2 - #3 friend for between the second and third bolts

content.description:
This route follows a large, left-facing dihedral to the left of

Le Dent

(5.6 R) for one long pitch. Excellent hand and fist jamming (crux) on clean rock leads to a flared chimney above. Because of the dihedral, this climb is not in the sun until the afternoon.
content.protection: a large rack, up to a #3.5 or #4 camalot

climbs.name: Le Dent
climbs.fa: Ivan Couch, Jim Donini, and Mike Dent

content.description: This route follows the right side of Le Dent pinnacle.  Pitch 1 is a fairly pleasant chimney.  Pitch 2 has an 80 foot runout on steep 5.6.  This route gets a lot of sun.
content.protection: a few medium to large pieces

climbs.name: Jammit
climbs.fa: Jim Donini, Ivan Couch, and Mike Dent

content.description: This is an excellent overhanging one-pitch hand crack.  It is in the shade after early morning.
content.protection: bring a number of hand-sized pieces

climbs.name: Holiday
climbs.fa: Nick Conway, Stuart Critchlow, and Alan Bartlett, April 1992

content.description: This route provides plenty of adventure.  It's a one pitch face climb with fairly sustained steep, balancy moves, and long runouts.  It's in the sun all day.
content.protection: 3 bolts and maybe one or two pieces of gear

content.description: Follow the short thin crack that curves to the right.  Good climbing, but it would be much better if the route was longer.
content.location: On the block that sits at the center of the base of the Le Dent Pinnacle.

climbs.name: Le Petite Gratton
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Mark Bowling, June 1988

content.description:
This route is the right arete counterpart to

South Arete

.  Start by doing a short crack just left of the right edge of the pinnacle.  Above the crack go over some small overlaps, passing two bolts on 11b climbing.  The upper half of the arete is runout, although the climbing gets progressively easier.

Some might give this route an "R" rating while others would argue that the upper climbing is easy enough relative to the overall grade that it doesn't need one.  Be forewarned, it is runout on easier ground.
content.protection: Bolts, and maybe a little gear for the opening crack.  Rapp from a horn.
content.location: The right arete of the Le Dent Pinnacle proper.

climbs.name: Floating Log
climbs.fa: Jonny Woodward and Darrell Hensel, August 1986

content.description:
Start by

Munge Dihedral

. A short crack leads to face climbing past three bolts, connecting the black knobs. The crux is between the second and third bolts. Above the bolts, follow the obvious cracks to the top.

Although worth doing this route is a bit loose and doesn't end up being quite as good as it appears it might be.  Hence...the name designated by Woodward.
content.location:
On the face just left of

Munge Dihedral

.

content.description:
This is the somewhat dirty right facing corner that forms the right side of the narrow pillar that hosts

Sugar Magnolia

.

The best thing this route has going for it is that it makes a good point of reference for describing how to find Steal Your Face.  Doesn't seem that it deserves a bomb though, unlike Jigsaw and The Source.  You want bad... go do those instead.
content.protection: Gear - sorry, don't remember what size anymore.
